author: Joshua Kosman
title: A fierce musical look at the hero of My Lai
text:
Photo: Nicholas Jensen Jonathan Berger composed the rich, evocative score. Jonathan Berger composed the rich, evocative score.
In the popular consciousness, the My Lai Massacre is primarily associated with one name: that of Lt. William Calley, the only U.S. serviceman to be convicted in connection with the horrific killings of hundreds of Vietnamese civilians on March 16, 1968. But “My Lai,” a fierce and often harrowing work of musical theater that had its unstaged premiere at Stanford’s Bing Concert Hall on Saturday night, focuses on a more heroic figure.
